Compressed Private Aggregation for Scalable and Robust Federated Learning over Massive Networks

Natalie Lang, Nir Shlezinger, Rafael G. L. D’Oliveira, and Salim El Rouayheb Parts of this work were presented in the 2023 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics Speech, and Signal Processing (ICASSP) as the paper [1]. N. Lang and N. Shlezinger are with the School of ECE, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Be’er-Sheva, Israel (e-mails: langn@post.bgu.ac.il; nirshl@bgu.ac.il). R. G. L. D’Oliveira is with the School of Mathematical and Statistical Sciences, Clemson University, SC (e-mail: rdolive@clemson.edu). S. El Rouayheb is with the Department of ECE, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ (e-mail: salim.elrouayheb@rutgers.edu).
Abstract
\Ac

fl is an emerging paradigm that allows a central server to train machine learning models using remote users’ data. Despite its growing popularity, federated learning (FL) faces challenges in preserving the privacy of local datasets, its sensitivity to poisoning attacks by malicious users, and its communication overhead. The latter is additionally considerably dominant in large-scale networks. These limitations are often individually mitigated by local differential privacy (LDP) mechanisms, robust aggregation, compression, and user selection techniques, which typically come at the cost of accuracy. In this work, we present compressed private aggregation (CPA), that allows massive deployments to simultaneously communicate at extremely low bit rates while achieving privacy, anonymity, and resilience to malicious users. CPA randomizes a codebook for compressing the data into a few bits using nested lattice quantizers, while ensuring anonymity and robustness, with a subsequent perturbation to hold LDP. The proposed CPA is proven to result in FL convergence in the same asymptotic rate as FL without privacy, compression, and robustness considerations, while satisfying both anonymity and LDP requirements. These analytical properties are empirically confirmed in a numerical study, where we demonstrate the performance gains of CPA compared with separate mechanisms for compression and privacy for training different image classification models, as well as its robustness in mitigating the harmful effects of malicious users.

I Introduction

The unprecedented success of deep learning highly relies on the availability of data, often gathered by edge devices such as mobile phones, sensors, and vehicles. As data may be private, there is a growing need to avoid leakage of private data while still being able to use it to train machine learning models. \Acfl [2, 3, 4, 5] is an emerging paradigm for training a model on multiple edge devices, exploiting their computational capabilities [6]. FL avoids directly sharing the users’ data, as training is performed locally with periodic centralized aggregations of the models orchestrated by a server.

Learning in a federated manner is subject to several core challenges that are not encountered in traditional centralized machine learning [5, 4]. Despite the training being performed locally and not involving data sharing, it was recently shown that private information can be extracted and that the data can even be reconstructed from the exchanged models updates by model inversion attacks, if these are not properly protected [7, 8, 9, 10]. Furthermore, the fact that training is done on the users’ side indicates that malicious users can affect the learned model by, for example, poisoning attacks [11, 12]. Another prominent challenge stems from the repeated exchange of highly parameterized models between the server and the devices during the FL procedure. As the communication links are possibly rate-limited channels, FL can notably load the communication infrastructure, which, in turn, often results in considerable delays and degraded convergence [13], [14]. These usually become more dominant in large-scale FL networks, causing significant overhead as well as yielding notable computational burden on the server side that recovers and aggregates the individual models, particularly when the number of users is huge, with possibly millions of participants.

Various methods have been proposed to tackle the above challenges: to preserve privacy, the LDP framework is commonly adopted. LDP quantifies privacy leakage of a single data sample when some function of the local datasets, e.g., a trained model, is publicly available [15]. LDP can be boosted by corrupting the model updates with privacy preserving noise (PPN) [16], via splitting/shuffling [17] or dimension selection [18]. An alternative privacy regime considered in FL is k𝑘k-anonymity, which involves mechanisms that render certain features indistinguishable [19, 20]. Both LDP and k𝑘k-anonymity mechanisms induce some level of perturbation that typically affects the learning procedure. Considering the difficulty of dealing with unreliable and malicious users, this issue is typically addressed by Byzantine robust methods [21, 22, 23]. Such techniques have the servers use non-affine aggregation which reduces the sensitivity to outliers and thus limits the harmful effect of corrupted model updates; yet typically degrade performance in the absence of malicious users.

The communication overhead of FL is often relaxed by reducing the volume of model updates via lossy compression. This can be achieved by having each user transmit only part of its updates by sparsifying or sub-sampling [24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29]. An alternative approach discretizes the updates of the model through quantization, so that it is conveyed using a small number of bits [30, 31, 32, 33, 34]. Scalability is typically enabled by limiting the number of participating devices through user selection [14]. These methods determine which of the users participate in each round of training, taking into account the individual constraints of computation and communication resources [35], as well as the magnitude of local updates [14].

Recent studies consider both the challenges of compression and privacy in FL. The works [36, 37] propose to quantize the local gradient with a differentially private 1-bit compressor; [38, 39] employ probabilistic quantizers to achieve compression in a manner that also enhances privacy, so that the incorporation of a dedicated PPN can result in the compressed representation obeying established multivariate LDP mechanisms [39]. All these schemes have the server separately recover the model updates for each user and then aggregate via conventional averaging. Thus, they are neither inherently scalable to suit massive systems and tolerate large groups of colluding users, nor account for robustness considerations.

In this work, we present a novel privacy preserving scheme designed for robust large-scale FL. The method, coined CPA, dramatically reduces communications by conveying model updates via messages of only a few bits, while providing k𝑘k-anonymity and LDP, as well as limiting the individual contribution of each user to increase robustness to malicious users. It is inspired by private multi-group aggregation [40] and geo-indistinguishability [41], which involve settings that fundamentally differ from FL in their task, yet inherently employ massive systems where scalability and robustness are key factors.

We design CPA by leveraging nested lattice quantizers [42] combined with random codebooks to encode the set of model updates into few bits at each user. The discretizing operation of the quantizers is exploited to provide anonymity, and is then further perturbed by incorporating an established randomized response (RR) mechanism. We analytically show that the resulting representation conveyed by each user rigorously holds both k𝑘k-anonymity and LDP guarantees, and empirically demonstrate that it utterly limits each user’s influence and leads to robustness from different forms of corrupted models. The conveyed few-bit representations are aggregated by the server via a decoding procedure, translating the received bits from all different users into an empirical discrete histogram over the model update values.

The aggregated mean of this histogram is shown to converge into the averaged global trained model, yielding the desired updated global model on each FL iteration. By doing so, the server does not reconstruct the individual model updates, which, when combined with the few-bit communication involved in CPA, notably facilitates the participation of numerous users and supports scalability. Furthermore, we systematically show that the distortion in the resulting aggregated model compared to vanilla FL (without communication, privacy, or security considerations) decreases as the number of users increases, and that the resulting model converges in the same asymptotic order as vanilla FL. These theoretical findings are numerically demonstrated in our experimental study. There, we evaluate CPA for learning several different image classification models, showing that its overall distortion is reduced compared to conventional methodologies for private compressed FL, and that this reduced distortion is translated into an improved performance of the learned model.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II briefly reviews the FL system model and the relevant preliminaries. CPA is presented in Section III, while Section IV theoretically analyzes its privacy guarantees and convergence profile. In Section V we numerically evaluate CPA. Finally, Section VI provides concluding remarks.

Throughout this paper, we use boldface lowercase letters for vectors, e.g., 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x}, boldface uppercase letters for matrices, e.g., 𝑿𝑿\boldsymbol{X}, and calligraphic letters for sets, e.g., 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. The stochastic expectation, variance, and ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm are denoted by 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathds{E}[\cdot], Var⁡(⋅)Var⋅\operatorname*{\text{Var}}(\cdot), and ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|, respectively, while ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} and ℝℝ\mathbb{R} are the sets of integer and real numbers, respectively.

II System Model and Preliminaries

In this section we present the system model of bit-constrained and private FL. We begin by recalling some relevant basics in FL and quantization in Subsections II-A-II-B respectively. We then review the privacy preliminaries in Subsection II-C, and formulate our problem in Subsection II-D.

II-A Federated Learning

In FL, a server trains a machine learning model parameterized by 𝒘∈ℝd𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} using data available at a group of K𝐾K users indexed by 1,…,K1…𝐾1,\ldots,K. These datasets, denoted 𝒟1,…,𝒟Ksubscript𝒟1…subscript𝒟𝐾\mathcal{D}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{K}, are assumed to be private. Thus, as opposed to conventional centralized learning where the server can use 𝒟=⋃r=1K𝒟r𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{r=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{r} to train 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w}, in FL the users cannot share their data with the server. Let Fr​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑟𝒘F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}) be the empirical risk of a model 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} evaluated over the dataset 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}. The training goal is to recover the d×1𝑑1d\times 1 optimal weights vector 𝒘optsuperscript𝒘opt\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt} satisfying

𝒘opt=arg​min𝒘⁡{F​(𝒘)≜1K​∑r=1KFr​(𝒘)}.superscript𝒘optsubscriptargmin𝒘≜𝐹𝒘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑟𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{w}}\left\{F(\boldsymbol{w})\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}F_{r}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)\right\}. (1)

Generally speaking, FL involves the distribution of a global model to the users. Each user locally trains this model using its own data and sends back the model update [5]. Therefore, users do not directly expose their private data, as training is performed locally. The server then aggregates the models into an updated global model and the procedure repeats iteratively.

Arguably, the most common FL scheme is federated averaging (FedAvg) [2], where the global model is updated by averaging the local models. Letting 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t} denote the global parameters vector available at the server at time step t𝑡t, the server shares 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t} with the users, who each performs τ𝜏\tau training iterations using its local 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r} to update 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t} into 𝒘t+τrsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau}. Typically, the information conveyed from the users to the server is not the model weights, i.e., 𝒘t+τrsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau}, but the updates to the model generated in the current round, i.e., 𝒉t+τr≜𝒘t+τr−𝒘t≜subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏subscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t+\tau}\triangleq\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau}-\boldsymbol{w}_{t}. As the server knows 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t}, it recovers 𝒘t+τsubscript𝒘𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}_{t+\tau} from the difference 𝒘t+τr−𝒘tsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏subscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau}-\boldsymbol{w}_{t}. The server in turn sets the global model to be

𝒘t+τ≜𝒘t+1K​∑r=1K𝒉t+τr=1K​∑r=1K𝒘t+τr,≜subscript𝒘𝑡𝜏subscript𝒘𝑡1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝜏1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{t+\tau}\triangleq\boldsymbol{w}_{t}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t+\tau}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau}, (2)

where it is assumed for simplicity that all K𝐾K users participate in each FL round. The updated global model is again distributed to the users and the learning procedure continues.

When the local optimization at the users’ side is carried out using stochastic gradient descent (SGD), then FedAvg applies the local-SGD method [43]. In this case, each user of index r𝑟r sets 𝒘tr=𝒘tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑟subscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t}^{r}=\boldsymbol{w}_{t}, and updates its local model via

𝒘t+1r←𝒘tr−ηt​∇Frjtr​(𝒘tr),absent←subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑗𝑟𝑡𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+1}\xleftarrow{}\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t}-\eta_{t}\nabla F^{j^{r}_{t}}_{r}\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t}\right), (3)

where jtrsubscriptsuperscript𝑗𝑟𝑡j^{r}_{t} is the sample index chosen uniformly from 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}, ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is the learning rate, and Frjtr​(⋅)subscriptsuperscript𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑗𝑟𝑡𝑟⋅F^{j^{r}_{t}}_{r}(\cdot) is the empirical risk computed using the jtrsubscriptsuperscript𝑗𝑟𝑡j^{r}_{t}-th sample in 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}. As sharing 𝒘t+τrsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑟𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{r}_{t+\tau} can possibly load the communication network and leak private information, it motivates the integration of quantization and privacy enhancement techniques, discussed below.

II-B Quantization Preliminaries

Vector quantization is the encoding of a set of continuous-amplitude quantities into a finite-bit representation [44]. Vector quantizers which are invariant of the underlying distribution of the vector to be quantized are referred to as universal vector quantizers; a leading approach to implement such quantizers is based on lattice quantization [45]:

Definition II.1 (Lattice Quantizer).

A lattice quantizer of dimension L∈ℤ+𝐿superscriptℤL\in\mathbb{Z}^{+} and generator matrix 𝐆∈ℝL×L𝐆superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿\boldsymbol{G}\ \in\mathbb{R}^{L\times L} maps 𝐱∈ℝL𝐱superscriptℝ𝐿\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} into a discrete representation Qℒ​(𝐱)subscript𝑄ℒ𝐱Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\boldsymbol{x}) by selecting the nearest point in the lattice ℒ≜{𝐆​𝐥:𝐥∈ℤL}≜ℒconditional-set𝐆𝐥𝐥superscriptℤ𝐿\mathcal{L}\triangleq\{\boldsymbol{G}\boldsymbol{l}:\boldsymbol{l}\in\mathbb{Z}^{L}\}, i.e.,

Qℒ​(𝒙)=arg​min𝒛∈ℒ⁡‖𝒙−𝒛‖.subscript𝑄ℒ𝒙subscriptargmin𝒛ℒnorm𝒙𝒛Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\boldsymbol{x})=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{z}\in\mathcal{L}}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{z}\|. (4)

To apply Qℒsubscript𝑄ℒQ_{\mathcal{L}} to a vector 𝒙∈ℝM​L𝒙superscriptℝ𝑀𝐿\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{ML}, it is divided into [𝒙1,…,𝒙M]Tsuperscriptsubscript𝒙1…subscript𝒙𝑀𝑇{[\boldsymbol{x}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{x}_{M}]}^{T}, and each sub-vector is quantized separately.

A lattice ℒℒ\mathcal{L} partitions ℝLsuperscriptℝ𝐿\mathbb{R}^{L} into cells centered around the lattice points, where the basic cell is 𝒫0={𝒙:Qℒ​(𝒙)=𝟎}subscript𝒫0conditional-set𝒙subscript𝑄ℒ𝒙0\mathcal{P}_{0}=\{\boldsymbol{x}:Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{0}\}. The number of lattice points in ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is countable but infinite. Thus, to obtain a finite-bit representation, it is common to restrict ℒℒ\mathcal{L} to include only points in a given sphere of radius γ𝛾\gamma, and the number of lattice points dictates the number of bits per sample - R𝑅R. An event in which the input to the lattice quantizer does not reside in this sphere is referred to as overloading, from which quantizers are typically designed to avoid [44]. In the special case of L=1𝐿1L=1 with 𝑮=ΔQ>0𝑮subscriptΔQ0\boldsymbol{G}=\Delta_{\rm Q}>0, Qℒ​(⋅)subscript𝑄ℒ⋅Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\cdot) specializes conventional scalar uniform quantization Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot).

Definition II.2 (Uniform Quantizer).

A mid-tread scalar uniform quantizer with support γ𝛾\gamma and spacing ΔQsubscriptΔQ\Delta_{\rm Q} is defined as

Q​(x)={ΔQ​⌊xΔQ+12⌋if ​x<|γ|sign(x)⋅(γ−12​ΔQ)else,𝑄𝑥casessubscriptΔQ𝑥subscriptΔQ12if 𝑥𝛾⋅sign𝑥𝛾12subscriptΔQelse\displaystyle Q(x)=\begin{cases}\Delta_{\rm Q}\left\lfloor\frac{x}{\Delta_{\rm Q}}+\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor&\text{if }x<\lvert\gamma\rvert\\ \operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(x)\cdot\left(\gamma-\frac{1}{2}\Delta_{\rm Q}\right)&\text{else},\end{cases} (5)

where R=log2⁡(2​γ/ΔQ)𝑅subscript22𝛾subscriptΔQR=\log_{2}\left(2\gamma/\Delta_{\rm Q}\right) bits are used to represent x𝑥x.

The formulation of lattice and uniform quantizers in Defs. II.1-II.2 gives rise to two extensions, which are adopted in the sequel. The first is Probabilistic quantization, which converts the quantizers to implement stochastic mapping. A conventional probabilistic quantization technique uses dithered quantization (DQ), which applies Qℒsubscript𝑄ℒQ_{\mathcal{L}} to a noisy version of the input [46, 47]. When the added noise is uniformly distributed over 𝒫0subscript𝒫0\mathcal{P}_{0} and the quantizer is not overloaded, the resulting distortion becomes an i.i.d. stochastic process [47, 48].

The second extension of lattice quantizers is nested quantization, which implements increased resolution quantization using multiple low-resolution quantizers. For simplicity, we now focus on nested quantization with two quantizers, as visualized in Fig. 1. The formal definition of a two-stage nested lattice quantizer is as follows [49].

Definition II.3 (Nested Lattice Codebook [50]).

A lattice ℒcsuperscriptℒc\mathcal{L}^{\rm c} is said to be nested in ℒfsuperscriptℒf\mathcal{L}^{\rm f} if ℒc⊂ℒfsuperscriptℒcsuperscriptℒf\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}\subset\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}. Let 𝒫0csubscriptsuperscript𝒫c0\mathcal{P}^{\rm c}_{0} denote the basic lattice cell of ℒcsuperscriptℒc\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}, then a nested lattice codebook ℒnsuperscriptℒn\mathcal{L}^{\rm n} based on the nested lattice pair ℒc⊂ℒfsuperscriptℒcsuperscriptℒf\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}\subset\mathcal{L}^{\rm f} is defined as

ℒn≜ℒf∩𝒫0c.≜superscriptℒnsuperscriptℒfsubscriptsuperscript𝒫c0\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}\triangleq\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}\cap\mathcal{P}^{\rm c}_{0}. (6)

A nested formulation allows quantizing with the fine lattice quantizer (ℒfsuperscriptℒf\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}) using the nested (ℒnsuperscriptℒn\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}) and the coarse (ℒcsuperscriptℒc\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}) ones. In particular, one can quantize 𝒙∈ℝL𝒙superscriptℝ𝐿\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} by computing Qℒf​(𝒙)=Qℒc​(𝒙)+Qℒn​(𝒙−Qℒc​(𝒙))subscript𝑄superscriptℒf𝒙subscript𝑄superscriptℒc𝒙subscript𝑄superscriptℒn𝒙subscript𝑄superscriptℒc𝒙Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}}(\boldsymbol{x})=Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}}(\boldsymbol{x})+Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}}\big{(}\boldsymbol{x}-Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}}(\boldsymbol{x})\big{)}. Nested lattice quantizers naturally specialize scalar nested quantization [42], where the nesting condition implies that the quantization spacing of the coarse quantizer must be an integer multiple of the corresponding spacing of the fine quantizer. While Def. II.3 is given for a two-stage quantizer, i.e., ℒfsuperscriptℒf\mathcal{L}^{\rm f} is implemented using two quantizers, it can be recursively extended into multiple stages by quantizing over ℒnsuperscriptℒn\mathcal{L}^{\rm n} in a nested fashion.

II-C Privacy Preliminaries

Privacy in settings involving queries between users and a server is commonly quantified in terms of differential privacy (DP) [51, 52] and LDP [53, 54]. While both provide users with privacy guarantees from untruthful adversaries, the latter does not assume a trusted third-party server, and is thus commonly adopted in FL [54, 55, 56, 15, 17, 18, 39]. Therefore, we consider LDP in this work, defined below.

Definition II.4 (ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP [57]).

A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP if for any pairs of input values v,v′𝑣superscript𝑣′v,v^{\prime} in the domain of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and for any possible output y𝑦y, it holds that

Pr⁡[ℳ​(v)=y]≤eε​Pr⁡[ℳ​(v′)=y].Prℳ𝑣𝑦superscript𝑒𝜀Prℳsuperscript𝑣′𝑦\displaystyle\Pr[\mathcal{M}(v)=y]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\Pr[\mathcal{M}(v^{\prime})=y]. (7)

We note that a smaller ε𝜀\varepsilon means greater protection of privacy. Def. II.4 implies that privacy can be achieved by stochasticity: if two different inputs are probable (up to some privacy budget) to be associated with the same algorithm output, then privacy is preserved, as each sample is not uniquely distinguishable.

For continuous quantities, common mechanisms that achieve ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP are widely based on perturbation with PPNs, e.g., Laplacian or multivariate t𝑡t [58]. The PPN distribution parameters set to meet the LDP privacy level ε𝜀\varepsilon. For private binary queries, a principle method for achieving ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP is the RR mechanism [59]. In RR, a user who possesses a private bit transmits it correctly with probability p>1/2𝑝12p>1/2. By (7), it can be shown that RR satisfies log⁡(p1−p)𝑝1𝑝\log\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right)-LDP [57] and can be viewed as a PPN mechanism.

Although LDP is a preferable privacy measure, it is often guaranteed by the introduction of a dominant PPN perturbations. Alternative privacy measures, which are not inherently bundled with stochasticity, are based on anonymization [57] such as k𝑘k-anonymity [60]:

Definition II.5 (k𝑘k-anonymity [60]).

A deterministic mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} holds k𝑘k-anonymity if for every input v𝑣v in the domain of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} there are at least k−1𝑘1k-1 different inputs {vi′}i=1k−1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑣′𝑖𝑖1𝑘1\{v^{\prime}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k-1} satisfying

ℳ​(v)=ℳ​(vi′),∀i∈{1,…,k−1}.formulae-sequenceℳ𝑣ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝑣′𝑖for-all𝑖1…𝑘1\displaystyle\mathcal{M}(v)=\mathcal{M}(v^{\prime}_{i}),\qquad\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,k-1\}. (8)

If ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies k𝑘k-anonymity, any observer of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}’s output is unable to discriminate between at least k𝑘k possible inputs.

II-D Problem Description

II-D1 Threat Model

\Ac

fl was shown to be exploitable by adversaries, with various possible attacks and threat models [61]. Here, we focus on two types of threats. The first is privacy attacks, i.e., algorithms that reconstruct the raw original private data, based on unintentional information leakage regarding the data or the machine learning model, being a unique characteristic of FL. Inspired by [62], we investigate an honest-but-curious server with the goal of uncovering the users’ data. The attacker is allowed to separately store and process updates transmitted by individual users, but may not interfere with the learning algorithm. The attacker may not modify the model architecture nor may it send malicious global parameters that do not represent the actual global learned model.

An additional threat considered is that of adversarial participants, often assumed in Byzantine robust FL [22]. Under this model, an unknown subset of the participating users may convey corrupted model updates, via poisoning attacks [11]. The identity of the unreliable users is not known to the server nor to the remaining reliable participants.

II-D2 Problem Formulation

Our goal is to design a global aggregation mechanism [5] for FL that provides privacy guarantees, compression, robustness, and is scalable. In particular, we are interested in obtaining a mapping 𝒉tr↦𝒘tmaps-tosuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑡𝑟subscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{h}_{t}^{r}\mapsto\boldsymbol{w}_{t} of the local updates at the r𝑟r-th user into the global model available at the server. The scheme must be:

  1. R1

    Private: holding k𝑘k-anonymity and ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP with respect to the private datasets {𝒟r}subscript𝒟𝑟\{\mathcal{D}_{r}\}, for a given anonymity degree k𝑘k and privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon, respectively.

  2. R2

    Compressed: communications to the server should involve at most B𝐵B bits per sample.

  3. R3

    Universal: invariant to the distribution of 𝒉trsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑡𝑟\boldsymbol{h}_{t}^{r}.

  4. R4

    Robust: resilient to adversarial participants and tolerate a large group of colluding users.

  5. R5

    Scalable: operable with possibly millions of participants.

In R1 we focus on achieving LDP in each round of communication. One can use a per-round privacy level to formulate an overall privacy guarantee after a given amount of rounds via the composition theorem [63, Thm. III.1.], as the overall privacy level after T𝑇T rounds is at most T⋅ε⋅𝑇𝜀T\cdot\varepsilon. Nevertheless, recent work has shown that by additional processing, a per-round privacy level can be translated into a multi-round one, obtaining an overall privacy budget depending on ε𝜀\varepsilon that does not linearly grow with the number of rounds [17]. For these reasons, we formulate our privacy budget as in R1.

Evidently, requirements R1-R3 can be satisfied by first perturbing the data to meet R1, followed by universal quantization to satisfy R2-R3, as both techniques are invariant to the distribution of 𝒉trsuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑡𝑟\boldsymbol{h}_{t}^{r}. However, the server decoding in these separate schemes requires individual reconstruction, which may result in violating R5 while not accounting for R4. Furthermore, both privacy and quantization can be modeled as corrupting the model updates, and thus using separate mechanisms may result in an overall noise which degrades the accuracy of the trained model beyond that needed to meet R1-R3. These observations motivate a joint design tailored for FL, studied next.

III Compressed Private Aggregation

In this section we introduce CPA, deriving its basic steps for 1-bit messages in Subsection III-A, and its extension to multi-bit messages via nested quantization in Subsection III-B. Then, we provide a discussion in Subsection III-C.

III-A 1-Bit CPA

We design CPA based on R1-R5 by extending the recent schemes of [40] and [41] to FL settings. Broadly speaking, CPA leverages the repeated communications of FL to generate a random codebook and encode the data with the help of an L𝐿L dimension lattice quantizer (holding R3). The generated code enables the transmission of a set of L𝐿L model update entries with a single bit, i.e., B=1L𝐵1𝐿B=\frac{1}{L} (satisfying R2), which guarantees k𝑘k-anonymity of the data. We then support LDP by applying RR to the transferred bits (satisfying R1). In the decoding procedure, the received bits are translated into an empirical histogram over the model update values, rather than recovering each model update separately (holding R5). The aggregated mean over this histogram converges into the FedAvg trained model, inherently limiting the influence of potential malicious participating users, as they can, at most, flip one bit (assuring R4). These steps, illustrated in Fig. 2 and summarized as Algorithm 1, are described below in detail.

III-A1 Initialization

To initialize CPA, the privacy parameters k𝑘k and ε𝜀\varepsilon are set, and the compression lattice ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is determined, i.e., fixing the dimension of the lattice L𝐿L, its generator matrix 𝑮𝑮\boldsymbol{G}, radius γ𝛾\gamma, and rate R𝑅R [64, Ch. 2]. We allow the lattice to change over the FL rounds, and thus denote it by ℒtsubscriptℒ𝑡\mathcal{L}_{t}. The motivation to do so is to allow the quantizer to adapt its mapping along the FL procedure, and particularly by gradually decreasing the dynamic range over time to better represent the model updates whose magnitude typically decreases as FL approaches converges. Additionally, a common seed srsubscript𝑠𝑟s_{r} is shared between each user and the server. This can be provided by the user along with the initial sharing of updates in the FL procedure, as done in, e.g., [33].

III-A2 Encoding

The CPA procedure is carried out on each FL global aggregation round. Therefore, we describe it for a given time step t𝑡t, in which the users have updated their local models. Since the encoding is identical for all users, we focus on the r𝑟r-th user, who is ready to transmit 𝒉trsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t}. In the encoding step, the model updates are compressed into a single bit using a quantizer and a random binary codebook, and then perturbed to enhance privacy. These steps are formulated as follows.

Quantization: To begin, 𝒉tr∈ℝdsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is divided into M≜⌈dL⌉≜𝑀𝑑𝐿M\triangleq\lceil\frac{d}{L}\rceil distinct L×1𝐿1L\times 1 vectors {𝒉t,ir}i=1Msubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑀𝑖1{\{\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}\}}^{M}_{i=1}, and quantized by applying an L𝐿L-dimensional lattice quantizer (Def. II.1) to each 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}, i.e., mapped into Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)subscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}).

1-Bit Compression: Next, the discrete codeword is compressed into a single bit according to the index of the assigned lattice point. To this end, the seed srsubscript𝑠𝑟s_{r} is used to randomize a codeword 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}, which is uniformly distributed over all words in {−1,1}2L​Rsuperscript11superscript2𝐿𝑅\{-1,1\}^{2^{LR}} having an equal amount of 111’s and −11-1’s. Then, as illustrated in Fig. 2, the lattice point Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)subscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}) is represented by its index in the lattice, denoted l𝑙l, and, in turn, a single bit b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i} is set according to the l𝑙l-th entry of the vector 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}.

Formally, we write Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)=𝒒lsubscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖superscript𝒒𝑙Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})=\boldsymbol{q}^{l} where 𝒒l∈ℝLsuperscript𝒒𝑙superscriptℝ𝐿\boldsymbol{q}^{l}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} is the l𝑙l-th lattice point in ℒtsubscriptℒ𝑡\mathcal{L}_{t}. The bit that the user conveys to the server is selected based on [𝒗t,ir]lsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑙{\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}\right]}_{l}, where

b¯t,ir≜{1if ​[𝒗t,ir]l=1,−1otherwise.≜subscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖cases1if subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑙11otherwise\displaystyle\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i}\triangleq\begin{cases}1&\text{if }{\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}\right]}_{l}=1,\\ -1&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (9)

The resulting processing converts the L𝐿L dimensional model updates vector 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i} into a single bit representation b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i}. This procedure is exemplified using a scalar quantizer in Fig. 3.

Privacy Enhancement: As we show in Section IV, k𝑘k-anonymity (Def. II.5) directly follows from the design of 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}. To also maintain ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP, RR is applied to b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i}. RR guarantees ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP by having the true value of b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i} conveyed with probability p=eε1+eε𝑝superscript𝑒𝜀1superscript𝑒𝜀p=\frac{e^{\varepsilon}}{1+e^{\varepsilon}} and its complement with 1−p1𝑝1-p. Consequently, the bit which the sever receives as a representation of 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i} is

III-A3 Decoding

The decoding procedure avoids having the server reconstruct each individual model. Instead, the server uses the bits it receives corresponding to the i𝑖i-th sub-vector of the model parameters to directly compute the desired aggregated model. This is achieved in two stages: first, the bits {bt,ir}r=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑟1𝐾{\{b^{r}_{t,i}\}}_{r=1}^{K} are recovered into unbiased estimates of their codewords {𝒗t,ir}r=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑟1𝐾\{\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}\}_{r=1}^{K}, which are directly aggregated into an empirical histogram, used to update the global model.

Recovery: Due to the shared seed srsubscript𝑠𝑟s_{r}, the server knows 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i} and can thus associate each bit with its corresponding codeword. However, since the bits are perturbed by the RR mechanism, the server can only recover an estimate of the codeword. This is achieved by setting

𝒗~t,ir=12​p−1​{𝒗t,irif ​bt,ir=1;(−1)⋅𝒗t,irotherwise,subscriptsuperscript~𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖12𝑝1casessubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖if subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖1⋅1subscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖otherwise,\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{r}_{t,i}=\frac{1}{2p-1}\begin{cases}\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}&\text{if }b^{r}_{t,i}=1;\\ (-1)\cdot\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}&\text{otherwise,}\end{cases} (11)

where the weighting factor 12​p−112𝑝1\frac{1}{2p-1} assures that 𝒗~t,irsubscriptsuperscript~𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{r}_{t,i} is an unbiased estimator of 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}.

Aggregation: The server then constructs with an aggregated mean of all {𝒗~t,ir}r=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript~𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑟1𝐾{\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{r}_{t,i}\}}_{r=1}^{K}, i.e.,

𝒗~t,i≜1K​∑r=1K𝒗~t,ir.≜subscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscriptsuperscript~𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{r}_{t,i}. (12)

Practically, 𝒗~t,isubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i} is a discrete normalized histogram. Aggregation through (12) can, in principle, yield negative histogram values, which can be kept or mitigated by thresholding [41].

The estimated histogram is utilized for updating the global model, replacing the conventional FedAvg update in (2) by

𝒘t,iCPA=𝒘t−τ,iCPA+∑l=12R[𝒗~t,i]l⋅𝒒l.subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2𝑅⋅subscriptdelimited-[]subscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖𝑙superscript𝒒𝑙\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t,i}=\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t-\tau,i}+\sum_{l=1}^{2^{R}}{\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}\right]}_{l}\cdot\boldsymbol{q}^{l}. (13)

The global model 𝒘tCPAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t} is then obtained by stacking the sub-vectors {𝒘t,iCPA}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑀{\{\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t,i}\}}_{i=1}^{M}.

III-B Nested CPA

Algorithm 1 is particularly designed to operate with a large number of users. Instead of recovering the individual model updates sub-vector of each user {𝒉t,ir}subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\{\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}\}, the aggregation of 𝒗~t,isubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i} in (12) forms an estimate of the distribution of the quantized updates over the lattice ℒtsubscriptℒ𝑡\mathcal{L}_{t}. As we show in Appendix -A, in the horizon of an asymptotically large number of users K𝐾K, the mean value taken over 𝒗~t,isubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i} converges to the federated average of {Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)}r=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑟1𝐾\{Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})\}_{r=1}^{K} for any given lattice quantizer employed. This motivates the usage of quantizers with high rate R𝑅R, for which the distortion in Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)subscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}) compared to 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i} is small. However, for a finite number of users, a large number of lattice points typically results in a less accurate estimation of the probability over the lattice via 𝒗~t,isubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}, giving rise to a tradeoff between the number of users K𝐾K and the quantization rate R𝑅R.

In order to alleviate this tradeoff, enabling CPA to operate reliably with high resolution lattice quantizers (large R𝑅R), we propose to implement fine quantization using multiple low-rate quantizers via nested quantization (Def. II.3). This allows constructing a separate histogram for each low-rate lattice quantizer, such that the mean over the fine lattice, i.e., the desired low-distorted averaged model, can be computed from these histograms. However, this comes at the cost of additional bits conveyed by the users, as each quantized value is no longer conveyed using a single bit as in Algorithm 1. We next formulate this form of nested CPA, focusing on a two-stage nested operation (i.e., with two bits B=2L𝐵2𝐿B=\frac{2}{L}), which can be extended to multiple stages (and multiple bits) as discussed in Subsection II-B. The general procedure is illustrated in Fig. 4.

III-B1 Initialization

In addition to the initial steps of Algorithm 1, nested CPA divides the fine lattice ℒtsubscriptℒ𝑡\mathcal{L}_{t} into a nested lattice ℒtnsubscriptsuperscriptℒn𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}_{t} and a coarse lattice ℒtcsubscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t} (see Def. II.3), with rates Rnsubscript𝑅nR_{\rm n} and Rcsubscript𝑅cR_{\rm c}, respectively.

III-B2 Encoding

As in Algorithm 1, the model updates are divided into {𝒉t,ir}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑀\{\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}\}_{i=1}^{M}. Here, the sub-vectors are quantized using the low-rate lattice quantizers, yielding

Qℒtc​(𝒉t,ir)=𝒒clc,Qℒtn​(𝒉t,ir−Qℒtc​(𝒉t,ir))=𝒒nln.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙ccsubscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒn𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖subscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙nn\begin{split}Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})=\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm c}}_{\rm c},\\ Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}_{t}}\big{(}\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}-Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})\big{)}=\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm n}}_{\rm n}.\end{split} (14)

The fact that Qℒtc​(⋅)subscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡⋅Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t}}(\cdot) and Qℒtn​(⋅)subscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒn𝑡⋅Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}_{t}}(\cdot) form a nested representation of the fine quantizer Qℒtf​(⋅)subscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒf𝑡⋅Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}_{t}}(\cdot) indicates that

Qℒtf​(𝒉t,ir)=𝒒clc+𝒒nln.subscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒf𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙ccsubscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙nnQ_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})=\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm c}}_{\rm c}+\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm n}}_{\rm n}. (15)

Each of the discrete representations in (14) is then separately mapped into a single bit through the 1-bit compression and privacy enhancement mechanisms detailed in Subsection III-A. For clarity, the nested extension of the 1-bit compression example given in Fig. 3 is depicted in Fig. 5.

III-B3 Decoding

Since the server has access to two bits for 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}, representing its coarse and nested quantization, it reconstructs two separate histograms for each lattice. By repeating the steps in (11) and (12), the server obtains two histogram estimates: one over ℒtcsubscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t}, denoted 𝒗~t,ic∈ℝ2Rcsuperscriptsubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖csuperscriptℝsuperscript2subscript𝑅c\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}^{\rm c}\in\mathbb{R}^{2^{R_{\rm c}}}, and another over ℒtnsubscriptsuperscriptℒn𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}_{t} denoted 𝒗~t,in∈ℝ2Rnsuperscriptsubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖nsuperscriptℝsuperscript2subscript𝑅n\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}^{\rm n}\in\mathbb{R}^{2^{R_{\rm n}}}. By (15), the averaging of {Qℒtf​(𝒉t,ir)}r=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄subscriptsuperscriptℒf𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑟1𝐾\{Q_{\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})\}_{r=1}^{K} is estimated as the sum of the empirical means over ℒtcsubscriptsuperscriptℒc𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm c}_{t} and ℒtnsubscriptsuperscriptℒn𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm n}_{t}, i.e., the aggregation in (13) is replaced with

𝒘t,iCPA=𝒘t−τ,iCPA+∑lc=12Rc[𝒗~t,ic]lc⋅𝒒clc+∑ln=12Rn[𝒗~t,in]ln⋅𝒒nln.subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑐1superscript2subscript𝑅c⋅subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖csubscript𝑙csubscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙ccsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑛1superscript2subscript𝑅n⋅subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript~𝒗𝑡𝑖nsubscript𝑙nsubscriptsuperscript𝒒subscript𝑙nn\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t,i}\!=\!\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t-\tau,i}\!+\!\sum_{l_{c}=1}^{2^{R_{\rm c}}}{\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}^{\rm c}\right]}_{l_{\rm c}}\!\cdot\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm c}}_{\rm c}\!+\!\sum_{l_{n}=1}^{2^{R_{\rm n}}}{\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}_{t,i}^{\rm n}\right]}_{l_{\rm n}}\!\cdot\boldsymbol{q}^{l_{\rm n}}_{\rm n}. (16)

The aggregation rule in (16) is designed to approach the corresponding rule obtained using 1-bit CPA in Algorithm 1 with the fine lattice ℒtfsubscriptsuperscriptℒf𝑡\mathcal{L}^{\rm f}_{t}, while using relatively easy-to-estimate histograms over smaller dictionaries. These nested extensions of CPA allows to facilitate the learning of an improved model in a federated manner when the number of users K𝐾K is limited, as numerically evidenced in Section V. There, notable improvements of the nested operation over 1-bit CPA are observed for K=10𝐾10K=10 users, which vanish for K=1000𝐾1000K=1000 users. This capability comes at the cost of additional bits being exchanged, though such increased communication is likely to be more tolerable when learning with tens of users compared with learning with thousands and more users.

III-C Discussion

The proposed CPA is a dual-function mechanism for enhancing privacy while compressing the model updates and aggregating in a robust fashion over large-scale FL systems. It is inspired by the coding scheme of private multi-group aggregation [40], with the incorporation of lattice quantization and LDP enhancement. The perturbation introduced in RR, originating from the need to meet R1, is mitigated here not by the conventional FedAvg as in, e.g., [33], but rather by a unique reconstruction of discrete histograms, which in turn guarantees k𝑘k-anonymity, as we show in Section IV. While CPA exploits the high-dimensional structure of the model updates through (possibly high-rate) lattice quantization, it still dramatically reduces the conventional FL communication overhead. This follows since the users transmit at most B𝐵B bits per sample, and the server avoids recovering the individual updates for each user. The resulting operation is thus scalable and applicable without limiting the number of participants in each FL round. In fact, its associated distortion decreases with the number of users, as shown in Section IV.

Moreover, because CPA inherently limits the influence of a user in the final model, it allows for the training to be Byzantine robust against erroneous adversarial users and poisoning attacks [22], as was also observed for one bit SGD with majority vote aggregation in [65] . This is numerically demonstrated in Section V. We note that CPA is expected to enhance privacy also against external adversaries, due to LDP post-processing property [56]. However, since FL is motivated by the need to avoid sharing local data with a centralized server, characterizing LDP guarantees from external adversaries is left for future work. Altogether, CPA satisfies R1-R5 without notably affecting the utility of the learned model, compared to using separate privacy enhancement and quantization, as numerically demonstrated in Section V.

CPA is designed assuming that all users share the same privacy requirement ε𝜀\varepsilon by R1. However, since the encoding of CPA is done separately by each user, one can extend its operation to user-specific privacy budgets. The direct approach simply has all users set their RR parameter p𝑝p to be the lowest non-flipping probability among all utilized LDP mechanisms, i.e., the one corresponding to the user with the most strict privacy requirements. Yet, it can possibly be that each user uses a different value of p𝑝p by modifying the aggregation rule at the server, though this extension and its analysis are left for future work. Furthermore, the privacy requirement considered in CPA is imposed on each communication round by R1. Traditionally, this requirement can be related to an upper bound on the privacy budget in FL over a fixed number of global training rounds by the composition theorem [63, Thm. III.1.]. Alternatively, additional mechanisms can be implemented to avoid accumulating privacy leakage over multiple rounds, as characterized by the composition theorem [17]. We leave the combination of CPA with such mechanisms for future study.

The nested implementation of CPA allows users to convey multiple bits per sample. By doing so, the server is able to construct smaller and therefore more accurate histograms, improving the global model update design in each FL round, particularly when K𝐾K is relatively small. However, with each bit added, the influence of each individual user on the constructed global model, being accordingly updated, grows and increases CPA’s sensitivity to malicious users. This gives rise to the existence of a tradeoff between model accuracy, compression, and robustness, whose analysis is left for future work.

IV Performance Analysis

CPA is designed to jointly support compression and privacy in FL over large-scale networks. Compression directly follows as each user conveys merely B𝐵B bits per sample. For 1-bit CPA, this boils down to merely M𝑀M bits, i.e., the number of bits is not larger than the number of weights. Consequently, we dedicate this section to theoretically analyze the privacy and learning implications of CPA, focusing on its 1-bit implementation for simplicity. We characterize its privacy guarantees (Subsection IV-A), distortion in its recovered global model (Subsection IV-B), and convergence profile (Subsection IV-C).

IV-A Privacy Analysis

As stated in Requirement R1, we are considering two privacy measures: LDP and k𝑘k-anonymity. The encoding steps of CPA are directly derived to meet the definitions of both privacy measures, as stated in the following propositions.

Proposition 1.

CPA is ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP with respect to 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r}, per communication round.

Proof:

ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP is obtained from the usage of RR in (10), indicating that bt,irsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖b^{r}_{t,i} holds ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP with respect to any data encapsulated in b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i}. Combining this with the LDP post-processing property [56], proves the proposition. ∎

The LDP guarantee in Proposition 1 follows solely from the usage of RR, and is invariant of the preceding processing of CPA. While in this work we further utilize probabilistic quantizers only for CPA’s distortion analysis (Subsection IV-B), one can possibly additionally enhance privacy in the algorithm’s quantization stage by a proper design of this stochastic compression technique, as shown in [39], though this extension is left for future study. Nevertheless, the quantization stage plays a key role in achieving k𝑘k-anonymity, as stated next.

Proposition 2.

CPA preserves k𝑘k-anonymity with respect to the lattice quantization of 𝐡t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}.

Proof:

k𝑘k-anonymity (Def. II.5) follows directly from the design of 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i}: since it is comprised of an equal amount of 111’s and −11-1’s, the server cannot distinguish between k≜2L​R−1≜𝑘superscript2𝐿𝑅1k\triangleq 2^{LR-1} candidates. As 𝒗t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{v}^{r}_{t,i} has at least k𝑘k identical entries for both ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1, then b¯t,irsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑏𝑟𝑡𝑖\bar{b}^{r}_{t,i} can originate from k𝑘k candidates for Qℒt​(𝒉t,ir)subscript𝑄subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖Q_{\mathcal{L}_{t}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}). ∎

For 1-bit CPA and a lattice quantizer of dimension L𝐿L and rate R𝑅R, it follows that k𝑘k-anonymity holds with k≤2L​R−1𝑘superscript2𝐿𝑅1k\leq 2^{LR-1}. While Proposition 2 formulates the anonymity degree of each sub-vector, Corollary 1 reveals the higher degree of anonymity achieved with respect to the complete model.

Corollary 1.

CPA preserves kMsuperscript𝑘𝑀k^{M} anonymity with respect to the lattice quantization of 𝐡trsubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝑟𝑡\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t}.

Proof:

The corollary follows directly from Proposition 2. The server cannot distinguish between k𝑘k different possibilities for each 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i} and 𝒉trsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t} is a concatenation of {𝒉t,ir}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑀\{\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}\}_{i=1}^{M}. Thus, each set of bits can represent kMsuperscript𝑘𝑀k^{M} different 𝒉trsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t} settings. ∎

The k𝑘k-anonymity of CPA characterized in Proposition 2 in fact guarantees the indistinguishability between k𝑘k possible values of the lattice quantization of 𝒉t,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i}. This follows from the nature of the k𝑘k-anonymity measure, which is defined over finite sets (see Def. II.5). However, by the operation of the quantization procedure, it collapses all the continuous values within a certain cell into the same decision, i.e., lattice point. This can be interpreted as a kind of \saycontinuous k𝑘k-anonymity, as, in addition to the indistinguishability between k𝑘k different lattice points guaranteed by Proposition 2, a quantized private value can potentially originate from any item in the uncountable set that covers the decision area mapped into this lattice point.

IV-B Weights Distortion

CPA incorporates lossy compression, RR, and a unique aggregation formulation that deviates from the conventional FedAvg. All of these steps inherently induce some distortion on the model updates, compared to the desired average of the model updates. To quantify this distortion, we characterize the difference between the model aggregated via CPA denoted 𝒘t+τCPAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t+\tau} obtained by stacking {𝒘t,iCPA}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝑖𝑖1𝑀{\{\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t,i}\}}_{i=1}^{M} in (13), with the desired average (whose direct computation gives rise to communication and privacy considerations) obtained from the same global model at time t𝑡t, given by

𝒘t+τFA≜𝒘tCPA+1K​∑r=1K𝒉t+τr.≜subscriptsuperscript𝒘FA𝑡𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝜏\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}_{t+\tau}\triangleq\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t+\tau}. (17)

Next, we show that the effect of the excessive distortion induced by CPA can be mitigated while recovering the desired 𝒘t+τFAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘FA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}_{t+\tau} as 𝒘t+τCPAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t+\tau}. Thus, the accuracy of the global learned model is maintained despite the incorporation of the scalable compression and privacy mechanisms of CPA. In our analysis we adopt the following assumption

  1. AS1

    CPA uses probabilistic quantization, i.e., Qℒ​(⋅)subscript𝑄ℒ⋅Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\cdot) implements DQ.

Probabilistic quantizers, as assumed in AS1, are often employed in FL, due to the stochastic nature of their associated distortion [25, 33, 30, 31], [39].

For a given probabilistic lattice quantizer defined using the lattice ℒℒ\mathcal{L} with lattice points {𝒒l}l=12Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒒𝑙𝑙1superscript2𝑅\{\boldsymbol{q}^{l}\}_{l=1}^{2^{R}}, we define σ¯ℒ2subscriptsuperscript¯𝜎2ℒ\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\mathcal{L}} to be the variance of the distortion induced by DQ with lattice ℒℒ\mathcal{L}. For CPA employing this lattice quantizer, the distance between the recovered model 𝒘t+τCPAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t+\tau} and the desired one 𝒘t+τFAsubscriptsuperscript𝒘FA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}_{t+\tau} satisfies:

Theorem IV.1.

When Assumption AS1 holds, the mean-squared distance between 𝐰t+τCPAsubscriptsuperscript𝐰CPA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t+\tau} and 𝐰t+τFAsubscriptsuperscript𝐰FA𝑡𝜏\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}_{t+\tau} is bounded by

𝔼​[‖𝒘t+τCPA−𝒘t+τFA‖2]≤MK​(∑l=12R‖𝒒l‖2(2​p−1)2+σ¯ℒ2).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝒘FA𝑡𝜏2𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2𝑅superscriptnormsuperscript𝒒𝑙2superscript2𝑝12subscriptsuperscript¯𝜎2ℒ\displaystyle\mathds{E}\left[{\big{\|}\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t+\tau}\!-\!\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}_{t+\tau}\big{\|}}^{2}\right]\leq\frac{M}{K}\left(\sum_{l=1}^{2^{R}}\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{q}^{l}\right\|^{2}}{{\left(2p\!-\!1\right)}^{2}}\!+\!\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\mathcal{L}}\right). (18)
Proof:

The proof is given in Appendix -A. ∎

Theorem IV.1 implies that the recovered model can be made arbitrarily close to the desired one by increasing the number of edge users participating in the FL training procedure, as (18) decreases as 1/K1𝐾1/K. This indicates the suitability of CPA for FL over large networks. However, while the difference decaying rate is of order 𝒪​(1/K)𝒪1𝐾\mathcal{O}(1/K), it is still affected by the need to compress the model updates and enhance their privacy. This is revealed in Theorem IV.1 via the presence of σ¯ℒ2subscriptsuperscript¯𝜎2ℒ\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\mathcal{L}} and p𝑝p, respectively, arising from each consideration. In particular, the moment σ¯ℒ2subscriptsuperscript¯𝜎2ℒ\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\mathcal{L}} follows from the distortion induced by lattice quantization, while p𝑝p accounts for the distortion induced by the RR mechanism. Specifically, p𝑝p is dictated by the privacy level ε𝜀\varepsilon, which implies that, as expected, stricter privacy constraints lead to additional distortion in the recovered global model.

IV-C Federated Learning Convergence

In the previous subsection we bounded the distortion induced by CPA in each communication round to achieve privacy and compression. Next, we show that this property is translated into FL convergence guarantees. To that aim, we further introduce the following assumptions, that are commonly employed in FL convergence studies in, e.g., [33, 66, 43], on the local datasets, stochastic gradients, and objectives:

  1. 2.

    Each dataset 𝒟rsubscript𝒟𝑟\mathcal{D}_{r} is comprised of i.i.d samples. However, different datasets can be statistically heterogeneous, i.e., arise from different distributions.

  2. 3.

    The expected squared ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of the vector ∇Frjtr​(𝒘)∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑗𝑟𝑡𝑟𝒘\nabla F^{j^{r}_{t}}_{r}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) in (3) is bounded by some ξr2>0subscriptsuperscript𝜉2𝑟0\xi^{2}_{r}>0 for all 𝒘∈ℝd𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  3. 4.

    The objective functions {Fr​(⋅)}r=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑟⋅𝐾𝑟1\{F_{r}(\cdot)\}^{K}_{r=1} are ρssubscript𝜌𝑠\rho_{s}-smooth and ρcsubscript𝜌𝑐\rho_{c}-strongly convex, i.e., for all 𝒘1,𝒘2∈ℝdsubscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}_{1},\boldsymbol{w}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} we have

    (𝒘1−𝒘2)T​∇Fr​(𝒘2)+12​ρc​‖𝒘1−𝒘2‖2≤Fr​(𝒘1)−Fr​(𝒘2)≤(𝒘1−𝒘2)T​∇Fr​(𝒘2)+12​ρs​‖𝒘1−𝒘2‖2.superscriptsubscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑟subscript𝒘212subscript𝜌𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒘1subscript𝒘22subscript𝐹𝑟subscript𝒘1subscript𝐹𝑟subscript𝒘2superscriptsubscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑟subscript𝒘212subscript𝜌𝑠superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒘1subscript𝒘22(\boldsymbol{w}_{1}-\boldsymbol{w}_{2})^{T}\nabla F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}_{2})+\frac{1}{2}\rho_{c}{\|\boldsymbol{w}_{1}-\boldsymbol{w}_{2}\|}^{2}\\ \leq F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}_{1})-F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}_{2})\leq\\ (\boldsymbol{w}_{1}-\boldsymbol{w}_{2})^{T}\nabla F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}_{2})+\frac{1}{2}\rho_{s}{\|\boldsymbol{w}_{1}-\boldsymbol{w}_{2}\|}^{2}.

Statistical heterogeneity as in 2 is a common characteristic of FL [3, 4, 5]. It is consistent with Requirement R3, which does not impose any specific distribution on the data. Statistical heterogeneity implies that the local objectives differ between users, hence the dependence on r𝑟r in 3, often employed in distributed learning studies [33, 66, 43]. Following 2 and [66, 33], we define the heterogeneity gap,

ψ≜F​(𝒘opt)−1K​∑r=1Kmin𝒘⁡Fr​(𝒘),≜𝜓𝐹superscript𝒘opt1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾subscript𝒘subscript𝐹𝑟𝒘\displaystyle\psi\triangleq F(\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}F_{r}(\boldsymbol{w}), (19)

where 𝒘optsuperscript𝒘opt\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt} is defined in (1). Assumption 4 holds for a range of objective functions used in FL, including ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm regularized linear regression and logistic regression [33].

The following theorem characterizes the convergence of FL employing CPA with local-SGD training:

Theorem IV.2.

Let ℒℒ\mathcal{L} be a lattice with generator matrix 𝐆𝐆\boldsymbol{G}, moment σ¯ℒ2subscriptsuperscript¯𝜎2ℒ\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\mathcal{L}}, and points {𝐪l}l=12Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑙𝑙1superscript2𝑅\{\boldsymbol{q}^{l}\}_{l=1}^{2^{R}}. The proof is given in Appendix -B. ∎

Theorem IV.2 rigorously bounds the difference in the objective value of a model learned by CPA with local-SGD at round t𝑡t and that of the optimal model 𝒘optsuperscript𝒘opt\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt}. By taking t𝑡t to be asymptotically large in (IV.2), we obtain the asymptotic convergence profile, indicating that CPA with local-SGD converges at a rate of 𝒪​(1/t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(1/t). This reverse dependence on t𝑡t was formed due to the specific design of the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} to gradually decreases, which is also known to contribute to the convergence of FL [43, 66], and the usage of a lattice with a gradually decaying dynamic range to fit the quantizer to the decaying magnitude of the model updates expected for converging FL. The asymptotic rate of 𝒪​(1/t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(1/t) is of the same order of convergence as FL with neither privacy nor compression constraints [43, 66], indicating the ability of CPA to satisfy these requirements while mitigating their harmful effects on the learning procedure.

In the non-asymptotic regime, the integration of compression and privacy techniques does influence model convergence, as revealed in Theorem IV.2 by the coefficient b𝑏b. The scalability of CPA is reflected in the first summand of (21), which vanishes as the number of users K𝐾K grows. The terms which do not vanish as K→∞→𝐾K\rightarrow\infty, i.e., the third and fourth summands in (21), stem from the usage of multiple local iterations per round and from the presence of statistical heterogeneity, respectively [66]; both are common properties of FL that are not targeted in our design of CPA.

V Experimental Study

In this section we numerically evaluate CPA and compare it to alternative approaches for compression and privacy in FL. We consider the federated training of different model architectures for handwritten digit identification with the MNIST dataset as well as image classification based on CIFAR-10. We quantify the distortion induced by CPA, the accuracy of the learned models, and the robustness to malicious users111The source code used in our experimental study, including all the hyper-parameters, is available online at https://github.com/langnatalie/CPA..

V-A Setup

We consider FL using local-SGD with the number of edge users varying from as small as K=10𝐾10K=10 to massive networks with K=1000𝐾1000K=1000, each studying different aspects in the design of CPA. We numerically evaluate the following schemes:

vanilla FL:

assuring neither privacy nor compression.

CPA:

1-bit CPA with a scalar quantizer;

CPA w/o RR:

1-bit CPA with a scalar quantizer without LDP constraints, i.e., ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\rightarrow\infty;

nested CPA:

two-stage nested CPA (see Subsection III-B) with Rc=1subscript𝑅c1R_{\rm c}=1, and Rn=3subscript𝑅n3R_{\rm n}=3;

Laplace:

Local updates perturbated by a Laplacian PPN, realize the Laplace mechanism [67] and satisfy only privacy.

signSGD & RR:

the common signSGD [32], which also utilizes 1-bit representations, followed by RR, realizing a straightforward separated design satisfying R1-R5.

JoPEQ:

the scheme of [39], which transforms randomized lattice quantization distortion into PPN, tackling R1-R3.

Unless stated otherwise, all benchmarks involve compression using a mid-tread uniform scalar quantizer with bit-rate R=1𝑅1R=1; and the ones holding ε𝜀\varepsilon-LDP set ε=0.5𝜀0.5\varepsilon=0.5.

V-B MNIST Dataset

First, the training of a linear regression model is evaluated for the handwritten digit identification task. We use the MNIST dataset, comprised of 28×28282828\times 28 gray-scale images divided into 60,0006000060,000 training examples and 10,0001000010,000 test examples; where each edge user possesses 555 uniformly drawn samples.

We begin by numerically validating that CPA indeed minimizes the excess distortion compared to individual compression and privacy enhancement operating with the same R1-R3. To this end, we consider FL with K={100,1000}𝐾1001000K=\{100,1000\} participating edge users, for different privacy budgets, i.e., ε𝜀\varepsilon values. We evaluate the observed SNR of the weights obtained by CPA compared to the desired FedAvg, which we compute as the estimated variance of the model weights and divide it by the estimated variance of the distortion, namely, Var⁡(𝒘FA)/Var⁡(𝒘FA−𝒘CPA)Varsuperscript𝒘FAVarsuperscript𝒘FAsuperscript𝒘CPA\operatorname*{\text{Var}}(\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA})/\operatorname*{\text{Var}}(\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm FA}-\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}); and report this in Fig. 8. Evidently, CPA attains fairly equivalent performance compared to the alternative of Laplace, which only meets R1 and R3, while satisfying R1-R5 altogether. The SNR of both schemes grows with looser privacy constraints and/or more users participating; while signSGD & RR demonstrates neither. This can be attributed to the coarse sign operation, whose distortion is so dominant such that it is sometimes reduced by privacy, and is barely influenced by the number of edge users taking part in the FL training.

Next, we evaluate how the reduced excess distortion of CPA is translated into an improved learning. We depict in Fig. 8 the validation set learning curves of all referenced methods. Fig. 8 indicates that CPA performs similarly to vanilla FL which satisfies neither privacy (R1) nor compression (R2), while simultaneously assuring both. We further observe that the straightforward signSGD & RR suffers from excessive distortion which deteriorates its learned model accuracy due to the usage of distinct mechanisms for quantization and privacy, as illustrated Fig. 8. A similar observation (though of a less notable gain) is noted in comparison to the joint design via JoPEQ operating with the same rate of one bit per sample.

We continue with numerical validation of the gains of nested CPA. As detailed in Subsection III-B, nested CPA alleviates the tradeoff between the number of users K𝐾K and the quantization rate R𝑅R. This is because for a limited number of users, a large number of lattice points typically results in a less accurate estimation of the probability over the lattice points, which in turn translates into degraded models. In Table I we can empirically view this behavior and the ability of the nested design to mitigate its harmful effects. We observe in Table I that the higher the number of users, the less the improvement of the nested operation over the 1-bit scheme for both accuracy and SNR. Since the considered model is a liner one, its associated loss surface is convex, implying noisy gradients might end-up deviating from the unique minimum; supporting the higher performance of CPA without RR (holding no privacy and therefore less noisy) over CPA.

Although the evaluation so far considers the learning of a linear regression model, we next show that CPA is beneficial regardless of the model specific design. We report in Table II the baselines’ converged models test accuracy results also for a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) with two hidden layers and intermediate ReLU activations; showing in line findings with the linear model. Table II also reports two CNNs trained for the CIFAR-10 dataset, detailed in the following.

V-C CIFAR-10 Dataset

We next learn a natural image classification model using the CIFAR-10 dataset. This dataset is comprised of 32×32323232\times 32 RGB images divided into 50,0005000050,000 training examples and 10,0001000010,000 test examples, uniformly distributed among K=1000𝐾1000K=1000 users. The examined architectures are CNNs composed of either two or three convolutional layers, denoted CNN2 and CNN3, respectively, followed by fully connected ones, with intermediate ReLU activations, max-pooling and dropout layers.

Table II reports the baselines’ converged models test accuracy results while Fig. 8 describes the validation set learning curves of all referenced methods for the CNN2 architecture. Unlike the handwritten digit classification, in the current task it is harder for the models to converge, particularly for signSGD & RR, which utterly fails to converge as revealed by Table II. For the CNN3 model, we can see that the performance of both CPA and JoPEQ is alike, yet the former holds R1-R5 while the latter only does so for R1-R3. It is noted that when training deep models, adding a minor level of distortion can improve the final model performance, see, e.g., [68, 69]. Hence, vanilla FL as well as CPA without RR do not necessarily outperform CPA with LDP consideration.

We conclude by verifying CPA’s toleration under colluding malicious participants. Table III reports the test accuracy of the converged models of the datasets and architectures considered. We simulate manipulations of a subset of the users, where it is either the scenario that a user is sending its 1-bit data constantly as 1′′{}^{\prime}1^{\prime}; or randomly flipping it; referenced to the result achieved with None. CPA’s immunity is observed regardless of the model and/or data chosen as Table III indicates a degrade of single percents in accuracy under the simulated attacks. This further ensures that CPA, in addition to being a joint compression and privacy mechanism for massive deployments, also provides robustness to Byzantine adversaries.

VI Conclusions

We proposed CPA, which realizes quantization and privacy in scalable and robust FL. CPA combines nested lattice quantization and encoding via a random codebook, with a dedicated RR mechanism and discrete histogram aggregations to yield provable desired privacy and anonymity levels in a manner that is scalable to large networks and resilient to malicious manipulations. Our analysis characterizes the excess distortion induced by CPA and its convergence, showing that it achieves similar asymptotic convergence profile as FL without privacy or compression considerations. We demonstrated that CPA results with less distorted and more reliable models compared to alternative compression and privacy FL methods, while approaching the performance achieved without these constraints and demolishing poisoning attacks.

-A Proof of Theorem IV.1

To prove Theorem IV.1, we separate the distortion induced by CPA into two terms and bound each of them separately. The first term is the error caused by the discrete histogram estimation in (12); the latter is the compression distortion.

As in Subsection III-A2, we denote by {𝒗i}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒗𝑖𝑖1𝑀{\{\boldsymbol{v}_{i}\}}_{i=1}^{M} the decomposition of a vector 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v} into M𝑀M distinct L×1𝐿1L\times 1 sub-vectors. Lemma -A.1.

For any {𝐡t+τ,ir}subscriptsuperscript𝐡𝑟𝑡𝜏𝑖\{\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t+\tau,i}\} it holds that the sequences {𝐞t+τ,ir}subscriptsuperscript𝐞𝑟𝑡𝜏𝑖\{\boldsymbol{e}^{r}_{t+\tau,i}\} and {ηt+τ,il}superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜏𝑖𝑙\{\eta_{t+\tau,i}^{l}\} are uncorrelated (over r𝑟r and l𝑙l, receptively), zero-mean, and mutually uncorrelated. Proof:

Combining this with the independence of the dither, the codewords, and the RR implies that 𝒆t+τ,irsubscriptsuperscript𝒆𝑟𝑡𝜏𝑖\boldsymbol{e}^{r}_{t+\tau,i} and ηt+τ,ilsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜏𝑖𝑙\eta_{t+\tau,i}^{l} are uncorrelated.

For ηt,ilsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑖𝑙\eta_{t,i}^{l}, we define η~t,il,r=δ​[Qℒ​(𝒉t,ir)−𝒒l]−[𝒗~t,ir]lsuperscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡𝑖𝑙𝑟𝛿delimited-[]subscript𝑄ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝒉𝑟𝑡𝑖subscript𝒒𝑙subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝒗𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑙\tilde{\eta}_{t,i}^{l,r}=\delta[Q_{\mathcal{L}}(\boldsymbol{h}^{r}_{t,i})-\boldsymbol{q}_{l}]-\left[\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{r}_{t,i}\right]_{l}. and thus ηt+τ,il=1K​∑r=1Kη~t+τ,il,rsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜏𝑖𝑙1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝐾superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡𝜏𝑖𝑙𝑟\eta_{t+\tau,i}^{l}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{r=1}^{K}\tilde{\eta}_{t+\tau,i}^{l,r} are i.i.d. zero-mean with variance not larger than 1K⋅(2​p−1)21⋅𝐾superscript2𝑝12\frac{1}{K\cdot{(2p-1)}^{2}}. ∎

Altogether, combining (-A.1) with Lemma -A.1 yields

-B Proof of Theorem IV.2

To prove the theorem, we derive a recursive bound on the weights error, from which the FL convergence bound is then concluded. This outline follows the steps used in [33], which did not consider privacy or anonymity guarantees. We next briefly describe the main steps for completeness, deferring the proofs of some of the intermediate lemmas to [33].

-B1 Recursive Bound on Weights Error

Denote by ℐτ≜{n​τ|n=1,2,…}≜subscriptℐ𝜏conditional-set𝑛𝜏𝑛12…\mathcal{I}_{\tau}\triangleq\{n\tau|n=1,2,\dots\} the set of global synchronization steps, i.e., t+1∈ℐτ𝑡1subscriptℐ𝜏t+1\in\mathcal{I}_{\tau} is a time step indicates communication of all devices. where b𝑏b is defined in (21). The relationship in (-B.6) is used in the sequel to prove the FL convergence bound in (IV.2).

-B2 FL Convergence Bound

We next obtain the convergence bound by setting the step-size and the FL parameters in (-B.6) to bound δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\delta_{t}; and combine the resulting bound with 4 to prove (IV.2). In particular, we set ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} to take the form ηt=βt+φsubscript𝜂𝑡𝛽𝑡𝜑\eta_{t}=\frac{\beta}{t+\varphi} for some β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and φ≥max⁡(4​ρs​β,τ)𝜑4subscript𝜌𝑠𝛽𝜏\varphi\geq\max(4\rho_{s}\beta,\tau), for which ηt≤14​ρssubscript𝜂𝑡14subscript𝜌𝑠\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{4\rho_{s}} and ηt≤2​ηt+τsubscript𝜂𝑡2subscript𝜂𝑡𝜏\eta_{t}\leq 2\eta_{t+\tau}, implying that (-B.3), (-B.1), and (-B.5) hold. Under such settings, in [33, App. C] is it proved that for λ≥max⁡(1+β2​bβ​ρc,φ​δ0)𝜆1superscript𝛽2𝑏𝛽subscript𝜌𝑐𝜑subscript𝛿0\lambda\geq\max\left(\frac{1+\beta^{2}b}{\beta\rho_{c}},\varphi\delta_{0}\right) is holds that δt≤λt+φsubscript𝛿𝑡𝜆𝑡𝜑\delta_{t}\leq\frac{\lambda}{t+\varphi} for all integer t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. Finally, the smoothness of the objective 4 implies that

𝔼​[F​(𝒘tCPA)]−F​(𝒘opt)≤ρs2​δt≤ρs​λ2​(t+φ).𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝒘CPA𝑡𝐹superscript𝒘optsubscript𝜌𝑠2subscript𝛿𝑡subscript𝜌𝑠𝜆2𝑡𝜑\displaystyle\mathds{E}\left[F(\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm CPA}_{t})\right]-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{\rm opt})\leq\frac{\rho_{s}}{2}\delta_{t}\leq\frac{\rho_{s}\lambda}{2(t+\varphi)}. (-B.7)

-B3 Proof of Lemma -B.1

To prove (-B.1), we separate it into two independent terms and bound each separately. Specifically,
